# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

datasetpaths = []
import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        datasetpaths.append(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.1220b6e1:
# Read in the csv file into a pandas dataframe
clickstream_df = pd.read_csv(datasetpaths[0]) 
clickstream_df.info()
source.8a0ac24d:
#Looking at only the entries with Duration not equal to zero (duration = 0 are clicks that were followed inmediatly by another click)
clickstream_df[clickstream_df['duration']>0]
source.0bae86fd:
# Simple visualization of the data
# Number of clicks for each title (top 50)
clickstream_df['title'].value_counts().nlargest(50).plot(kind='barh', figsize=(20, 11))
source.71b4461f: Here we just take a quick look to check everything went well
source.cb7a91ad: Now let's try a filter. The duration field has the number of seconds until that user made ***any*** another click. Here we filter for duration not equal to zero.
source.7daf5245: That worked great! Now let's try a simple visualization. First we count how many times did each title appear in the dataset. We take the top 50 and then show them in a bar plot.
source.f980e782: We only have one file, so the path is simply datasetpaths[0]. Below we read it into a pandas dataframe
